Comment: Wave period of waves at peak of wave energy spectrum.
Direction for waves at peak of wave energy spectrum from which the waves are coming.
Directional spread of waves at peak of wave energy spectrum.
Significant wave height derived from wave energy spectrum.
Energy period derived from spectral moments, m-1 and m0.
Mean wave period derived from spectral moments, m0 and m1.
Mean wave period derived from spectral moments, m0 and m2.
Maximum wave height measured during the period of observation.
Period of maximum wave height measured during the period of observation.
Average wave height of all the upcrossing waves measured during the period of observation.
Average wave period of all the upcrossing waves measured during the period of observation.
Acoustic current meter mean current direction, defined as direction the water particles are moving towards.
Acoustic current meter mean current speed.
The water temperature close to the ocean's surface. A measure of how hot or cold the water is.
Wave period of the highest wave.
The zero upcrossing period is defined as the time interval between consecutive occasions on which the surface height passes upward above the mean level.
The pressure exerted by the weight of the atmosphere.
The wind vane points into the oncoming wind and the 10 minute average wind direction is recorded. Reported Hourly.
The average wind speed (knots) for 10 minutes. Reported Hourly.
The maximum wind speed measured over 3 seconds. Reported Hourly.

Wave height is calcluated as four times the RMS (Root Mean Square Value) of the wave. This value then gives you the change in height.  The sensor measures this for 17.5 minutes and then takes an average.
A record of 17.5 minutes of the number of times a wave passes through mean water level in an upward direction.
The mean direction from which the waves are coming over the period of measurement.
Air temperature is a measure of how hot or cold the air is.
The atmospheric temperature (varying according to pressure and humidity) below which water droplets begin to condense and dew can form.

Salinity in rivers, lakes, and the ocean is conceptually simple, but technically challenging to define and measure precisely. Conceptually the salinity is the quantity of dissolved salt content of the water.
The amount of water vapour present in air expressed as a percentage of the amount needed for saturation at the same temperature.
